text:
Thanks for passing me and
my candidacy for my defense 35 years ago. So it was 35 years ago,
this week, that I left,

actually, Stanford for Caltech. Many of you didn't have
the great opportunity that I did to get advice
from Bernie Roth in your PhD.

So I will pass on one that he
told me right before I went out for my first job talk. He said, Joel, on your best
day ever, 10% of your audience

will sleep. Just get over it. And so Bernie, you can lead the
chorus of snorers right now.

So besides having spent
40 years in robotics, I also work on
biomedical devices.

But today, I want
to use, actually, a cheesy over the top
biomimetic inspiration.

So I started working on my
first robots over 40 years ago. And we don't
actually have robots

that can do this today,
whereby, you can swoop down. As you'll see later,
have to carefully control

the feathering of your
wings near the ground, because of a ground effect. You have to actually interact
and generate a lot of forces

to control the
grasping of that fish. And I'm even more ambitious. I'd like to be able to
do something like this,

while there's a big wind. And then maybe the person who
owns that fish pond is not real happy and throws
a shoe at this bird

as well for poaching that fish. So I don't know how to solve
all these problems yet. But we're working on pieces
that we'd like to put together.

And so I'm going to tell you
about some of the pieces today that, hopefully, will get us to
this future of high performance

in dynamic tasks. So using the biological
idea for a minute,

this are two model
organisms that I've been evolving in my lab. The first one is called SQUID.

It's a streamlined quick
unfolding investigative drone. And the practical
motivation is this.

This work was funded
by the military. And so what they'd
like to have is if military are out
on patrol, and they

want to be able to quick
get an eye in the sky to see what's happening, for
me, I'm actually quite inspired

by the, unfortunately,
unpleasant fact that we have lots of
fires in California. And plenty of
firefighters, oftentimes,

get trapped in flames. And so it would be good if they
could also quickly get something into the sky very quickly to get
surveillance of what's happening

in the nearby environment. So to launch a drone
today, you, typically, have to put it on the ground,
and then manually help

the launching process. Drones, sometimes, are failure
proof or failure prone,

once they take off. Also, they can't actually be
shot off a moving vehicle.

And moreover, they take
time to unfold and deploy. So we spent a couple
of years working

on a couple of generations of
these SQUID devices, which can then ballistically be launched.

And so our first
SQUID, as you see here, looks like a World
War II V-2 rocket, because that's the most
streamlined design possible.

It's the same diameter
as a baseball, because this is a
baseball pitching machine that launches it. And the simple theory in
this first version talking

about dynamic
tasks and stability is, actually, if you design this
thing so that at every instant

the center of gravity is
above the center of pressure during the arm
unfolding process, it will be passively stable.

So this is, actually, out in
the desert about two hours north of Caltech. We, actually, were
shooting these things

off a truck at 50 miles an hour. And so here's showing
you the launch process.

There's, actually, a
computer controlled mechanism that releases the
arms at a predetermined height. In this early version, there's,
actually-- you can't see it.

There's, actually,
a world-class pilot on the side of the road,
who then takes over control.
It helps stabilize it.

So here, you'll see the bird's
eye view of the launch process.

And so after a little bit
of tweaking and tweeting, the simple theory of a
passive aerodynamic stability actually worked 100% of
the time quite reliably.

So the next thing we
started looking at is can we, actually,
autonomously stabilize these vehicles.

And so this is larger. We call it SQUID II. Or as my students
call it the kraken, because it actually
weighs three kilograms.

It can really hurt you
at 70 miles an hour, if you're not careful. And so this one actually
has onboard autonomy.

So there's onboard
LiDARs and cameras and computing and things. We also, because we wanted to
launch it at higher speeds.

And, also, we found
out from our first one that these drones experienced
forces over 100 gs

during the launch process. So you can imagine, if you're
shot out of a cannon at 100 gs, all your sensors are going
to be completely kerflooey.

And so we have to make
this careful balance between passive
stability, when we launch,

and then transition over
to active stability, and figure out which
sensors can actually be deployed at which time.

And, also, how to
stabilize this. So we developed
a scaling theory,

which would allow us then
to use an open air wind tunnel at Caltech that you'll
see prominently several times

today. But used so that we can launch
little two-inch prototypes. And if we can stabilize these
little two-inch prototypes

in the wind flow, which
is coming this way, launch at different
angles, the theory would tell us that
we would actually

be passively stable up to about
80 miles an hour launch speed.

This is in the Center
for Autonomous Systems and Technologies at Caltech. It's, basically, a drone
arena and a robot arena.

In this particular
version, we, actually, release the propellers,
and release these fins.

So these large fins, actually,
poke out of the wake stream so that it passively
stabilizes itself

in a large range of conditions. And so what you'll
see then is there's a sequence of sensors turning
on after they're blacked out

from the 100 G-Force
of launching. And then we primarily
then-- the only sensor that really works throughout
the launch process

is computer vision. So we use computer vision
to stabilize these things until they reach a
sufficient height

and, actually, then reach
sufficient stability or quietness of the sensors. So they can take over and
act like a regular drone.

Now, the problem
is this thing will work 100% of the time
in a fairly steady wind. But if you have a
really complex wind

like in the case of
the firefighters, we're not sure whether
this thing will be stable.

But this stability was
enough that we've actually convinced the JPL, the
Jet Propulsion Laboratory,

to change how the
future missions to Mars will be done by helicopters. So many of you are familiar
with the current Mars helicopter

which has been a great success. It can only carry about
a 50-gram payload. But because of our work, we're
now involved in two projects

that I'll tell you about
today, with JPL to look at future drones for Mars. The first one is to
use small ones, like,

the one that you saw here,
which could be then launched out of an aeroshell in
a larger mission to, actually, drop multiple
investigators over the planet.

The real one we're
looking at right now is the [INAUDIBLE]
Mars helicopter that's funded by Congress. It will be about 13 feet in
diameter, and a hexacopter,

and carry about a three-
to five-kilogram payload. And because of the
work that we've done, we've shown that we're able to
actually launch this in mid-air.

So instead of landing
it on the ground, it'll actually be deployed
about five kilometers above the surface.

And then flutter
down, which will allow us to get to
new science areas that we can't get to right
now and drastically reduce

the cost of the mission. Now, the other
problem that we're faced with in the Future
Mars helicopter mission

is the ability to do science. That's, actually, what
drives all these missions in NASA and Congress.

And so what the current
rovers on Mars have found is that some of the most
interesting geological

and scientific
treasures are actually on the sides of very,
very steep slopes. And so the question is,
how do we get there?

And so with the
limited payload that we have from the current
even future designs,

it's almost impossible
to get there. So the current idea is instead
of sending rovers or astronauts

there, is to actually
use a helicopter, but in the following way. So you would drop the
helicopter in the atmosphere.

And then drop a payload of
a bunch of different sensor modules down on the ground. The helicopter
would then actually

go find the sensor modules,
go do some reconnaissance, and figure out where it
would be an interesting spot

to place these modules. Then, actually, pick
up these modules. And then go have them
grip onto the walls.

And the technology you use,
as you'll see in a second, is the microspine grippers
that, actually, came out of Mark Kutkosky's lab.

So one of the things
you can imagine-- and this is where we've been
pushing the envelope-- is that, actually, these sensor modules
will be very heavy, especially,

compared to the
weight of the drone. So those of you familiar
with aerial manipulation know that trying to manipulate
a very heavy payload on a drone

is a tough problem,
because as you're shifting the center
of mass around it, it can become quite unstable. It requires huge,
huge lifting forces

that are impossible to get
from conventional drones. So we have two innovations. One of which I'll
talk about today.

And one, maybe,
in a future talk. One innovation is
a practical design. So this is a payload
shifting arm that

actually deposits the sensors. So, actually, the batteries
and CPU are actually back here.

So as this extends
out, we actually maintain the center of mass
to within about two or three centimeters of native one.

And so the idea then is that
this arm has a special end

effector here, which can
then deposit these payloads. These payloads have Mark's
microspine gripper on them,

then batteries, computers, and
up to 500 grams of sensors. So the whole thing weighs
about a kilogram and a half.

And this drone is
only 3.5 kilograms. So we're talking about 40%
of the payload of the drone. The other innovation
is some new work

on differential flatness
and nonlinear control using differential flatness. But we don't really
need it here.

And so these micro
spine grippers, because of Mark's brilliant
work and Aaron Parness can, actually, hold
these sensors up

for over a month at a time. And then we've built
an interface here. So not only can we deposit
them, but we can, actually,

retract them and then go
replace them as we go forward. So here's the basic
idea and why it's

closer to that biomimetic
idea that I showed before. We can't just touch
and go like most people

do in aerial manipulation. We, actually, have to
do a lot of manipulation with the environment to get
these things to be stable.

So the idea is we
use an onboard camera to take a target identified
by human operator.

Insert a servo on that. Then we, actually, contact the
wall and press into the wall.

So, we get sufficient forces. And then the microspine gripper
coordinates with the computer to close and grip.

Then, actually, the drone
using a force sensor pulls on the sensor
to test that it's OK.

And then it releases. So let's see all that in action. Again, this is in our
drone facility at Caltech.

So this is manual,
at this point. Now, it's switching
over to autonomous. This tether is not necessary.

It's just for a
requirement for safety. So now you're seeing it
extending out the arm. , Again you're seeing it keeps the
stable balance relatively easy,

because of the mass
shifting capability. At the end of the arm,
is the payload there? That thing is the sensor.

That's actually a basalt rock. Actually, that's very similar
to a native basalt on Mars.

There you can see the close up,
and then over on the side there, you can see actually all the
data in terms of either position

or later actually
in terms of forces. And so, now, it's
pushing, it's coordinating with the microspine gripper.

It pulled on it. And then it of found
that it could detach. So this is great. We're very happy with this.

But we're now interested not
only on Mars, but actually, doing this in the real world.

And so how can we take
things like the kraken that I showed you
before and work them

in very complex
flows like in a fire or take this and work in
the outside world, where

you may have things like,
when these vehicles get close to a wall, there's an
interactive fluid structure

interactions that actually cause
complex forces to be applied to the drones.

And, particularly, if you're
working in close proximity in some building or other
kinds of things to flow,

they're very complex and make
the control very difficult. The other thing is
out in the real world.

We're also going to have lots
of winds and biases, et cetera. So how can we adapt
to these effects?

So I'm going to talk about
two techniques today. So the first one, for those
of you who read my abstract,

is based on the idea
of a Koopman operator. But before I get into
the ideas of that,

let me just give
you a survey of, actually, how pretty much all
learning for flight control, and, actually, even general
robotic vehicle control goes.

And so the idea is assume that
you have some dynamical system, we can describe its governing
mechanics by some equation,

x dot equals f, the dynamics
of x, the state u, the control and w is some disturbance or
unknown force or unmodeled

dynamics. So you can either say, hey, I've
got a nominal control system. So in drones, we can just use
the onboard usual controller,

when you're actually
out not near a buildings or in complex flows. And that works pretty well. But when you're in a
complex environment,

then what you may
want to do is learn this disturbance, as we call
it, or residual, as we call it.

So this is called
residual learning. The other-- and I'm going
to talk about that-- second, the other approach is
you can actually try

to learn the dynamics directly. And for particular
reasons, because if you can learn the dynamics
directly, then you

can apply actually
control techniques, where you can get things like
guaranteed stability, guaranteed

safety, and also start to answer
questions about how much data

do I need to learn, et cetera. So what we'd like
to do is to not only be safe during
deployment, but, actually,

be safe in rigorous and stable
and provable during the learning process as well.

So I know these techniques are
not yet popular at Stanford. Although, I know
Marco Pavone's group is working with George Haller on
things that are related to it.

But if you've never seen
Koopman techniques before, the idea is very
straightforward. So if I start with an
autonomous dynamical system,

x dot equals f of x. I'm ignoring the
control right now. Normally, what you
do is you study the flows of that dynamical
system, which may be nonlinear.

And you study the geometry
of the phase space. And so all the theory is based
on how these geometries evolves

over time to study stability, or
robustness, or convergence, et cetera. Back in 1932, Koopman
came up with this idea,

which was basically lost to
time until around 2000, when it was rediscovered
by a person who

was doing his PhD at
Caltech, Igor Mezic, And what Koopman said is instead
of looking at the state space,

let me define a
space of observables. So an observable is thing
like momentum, energy. It could be the
actual coordinates

of the state system as well. But that space now is a
function space, instead of a finite dimensional
state space.

And what Koopman showed
is that, actually, there's an equivalent linear,
but infinite dimensional

system, which, actually,
mimics the dynamics of this finite dimensional
nonlinear system.

And so in theory,
then, if you're willing to pay the
price to lift this to very, very high
dimensions, you can then use linear
control theory on this.

Potentially, there's a
problem we'll see in a second. Now, in practice,
no one wants to work with an infinite dimensional
system in a real engineering

system. So what people do then is
lift this up to-- let's say, you have a three-degree
of freedom system here,

you might lift this to 14
dimensions, 15 dimensions, and make a finite approximation
to this infinite dimensional

lifting. But the thing that
you know is if you're willing to pay that price is
you get a truly linear system.

It's guaranteed to be linear. Now, the finite dimensional
approximation, there are some issues. And there's still ongoing
work to understand the effects

of those approximations. So now, when we
add control inputs, it's not quite as pleasant.

And what you find
is that, actually, when you try to do
that lifting process,

the autonomous part goes fine. That, actually, does lift
to, actually, linear part.

But the control part doesn't. It lifts to very complicated
equation right here.

But under certain
conditions, which are satisfied for almost
all relevant engineering and robotic systems, what you
can show is all this term here

collapses down. And by change of
coordinates can be made a simple product of a constant
matrix g times a vector

z, which is the
lifted variables. So it's a bi-linear system. So it's not quite linear.

But it's bi-linear. And so there's a rapidly
growing, actually,

research field in this area. And so what our group
has been working on is, how do we actually learn
these bi-linear systems directly

from data? That's the brilliance
of the Koopman idea is that because you're working
in the space of observables,

you don't have to
measure the state. What you do is you measure,
actually, how the system looks to you in the real world.

And that gives you the indirect
information about what's happening in the state space.

So now, the problem
is, of course, is both how do we
do this from data. And the other thing
is the original theory

that developed these techniques
assumed that, actually, all the control inputs that
you use to ID the system

were open loop, which is
a disaster for robotics, of course. You can't just run
your robot around. And let it crash everywhere.

So we've developed a
number of techniques. And the reason we
like the Koopman thing is because, then, you
can use the favorite tool

that robot engineers
love to use, which is model predictive control. So this is an optimal
control technique.

So you have some cost function. So now, the cost
function is going to be in the control
inputs like, regular model

predictive control. And it's now going to
be in the lifted states. So you use regular
linear MPC-like ideas.

Again, the key advantage of
using these Koopman techniques is if you can learn this
model, then you can, actually,

do control with constraints. In reinforcement learning,
you can't, actually, learn and, actually, have
constraints taken into account.

So this learning method,
any kind of constraint that you can
imagine, we can build into the calculation
process, and, in effect,

into the learning process. So we can learn
with constraints, execute with constraints. And that's what real
engineers love to do.

So now, because it's a bi-linear
system and not truly linear, we have to do an
approximation in the MPC.

So I'm talking with lunch
today with most people. It seems like you guys are
familiar with sequential quadratic programming.

And so we use a sequential
quadratic programming technique to do that. So because I wanted this to be
more of an overview talk today,

and not too technical, you'll
see a bunch of list of papers here. If you want to go through
a fine further details.

So I'm just going to gloss
through this one quickly. Those of you who are
familiar with fluid mechanics

and know something about DMD,
dynamic mode decomposition, we've figured out the equivalent
of dynamic mode decomposition

for these robot
control problems. And so the idea is you
fly your drone around,

or you drive your
vehicle around, and you gather a bunch of data. You go through a
bunch of calculations

and out pops a
bi-linear approximation of a particular dimension
that you have to, actually, specify ahead of time.

So that's still
an open question. I'm not going
through many details there, because it seems
like most of the world

these days is
interested in deep nets. And so just recently, last
year, one of my students

figured out actually
how to put all of this in a deep neural network. You can go see the details. But I'm going to give you
the concept right now.

So in order to do this
Koopman learning, what we want to figure out
is how do we lift. So we need this
lifting function,

which is called a
Koopman eigenfunction. So you need to learn
the eigenfunction. So we use that auto-encoder to,
basically, minimize the error

between the projection
of the lifted function and the actual state
data that we get.

Then you have a part
which, actually, looks at how good is the
predictive capability

of this lifted model. You want it to be able
to mimic the system. And then, finally,
we have a part, which actually learns the
bi-linearization of the system.

And so you can then have a
deep neural network, which, actually, has three terms. It's make a good lifting,
make it predict well,

and make sure you learn
the dynamic F and G matrices properly.

So let's see this in action. So here's a little crazy fly. Maybe those of them, these
are five- or six-inch diameter

drones. And so this is again in our
flight arena at Caltech. So on the top is after
three minutes of training.

This is what actually
our Koopman model can do. On the bottom is a state
of the art nonlinear model

predictive control. So when we're having
them, actually, fly at 25 centimeters or 10
inches above the ground,

the ground effect is there. But it's not very large. So both of these
things look equivalent.

But, actually, if
you look carefully at the data, what you find
out is the Koopman model,

actually, learns the
ground effect very well. So it's actually able
to keep the desired 25-centimeter height.

The ground effect actually adds
extra buoyancy to the drone. And so what happens is it
flies the right trajectory.

But it's way too high,
because it doesn't understand these buoyant forces. And it also doesn't understand
how the buoyant forces

vary with height. So now, let's, actually,
try to have these drones fly

below the level, where,
actually, the ground effect is really important. So this is less than the
diameter of the drone.

And so what you see in the
bottom is the nonlinear model predictive control,
actually, crashes repeatedly. It, actually, can't fly.

We can, actually,
get these drones down to one inch above the
surface at full speed and, actually, control
them without crashing

or being unstable. So there's a little
bit about learning.

The second part of my
talk was about risk. And I'm going to couple the
two at the end of each other.

And so this is a huge
problem in robotics. I'm not the first
person to study this. There's much active
work here at Stanford,

which is why I wanted to
talk about this today. In fact, Professor Pavone
wrote a lovely, lovely paper

on the role of risk in robotics. And so, in general, not
even necessarily thinking about risk, what
you'd like to know

is if robots are
now going to operate in human-like environments,
where there's kids playing ball, and dogs running around,
and cars are driving,

how should they model the world? How should they
plan their motions to account for all
the uncertainty?

And we're also dealing
with learning systems. So, actually, how should
they account for the fact that they actually don't fully
understand their learned models

as well? And so, classically,
at lunch today, I heard some of you working on
stochastic motion planning.

That's great. So these kinds of
problems can be formulated in the following way.

I want to plan a trajectory. And it deals with
uncertain systems. So I have an uncertain
model of the world.

Choose your favorite
distribution. We'll talk about that later. And so I'll take
some cost function, which may be nonlinear.

And I'll try to minimize
that cost function, even with the unmodeled or
partially modeled disturbances.

And then, potentially,
with some constraints that deal with the fact that
I don't want to bump into kids or crash my drone or
crash into another car.

So the major approaches
up until a couple of years ago were either, again,
planning an expectation.

So you figure out what's the
expected value of the problems that you're going to face. And, also, make what's called a
chance constraint to make sure

that your constraints
have not bumping into things are probabilistic. So you want to make sure there's
a minimum probability that I

don't clash or crash into
something using some physics model of how I would crash, or
how I would bump into people.

Or you could use minimax
or worst case planning, which is minimize the maximum
worst case of this function,

again, using constraints. But we don't have to
use those two extremes.

There's actually
extremes in the middle. And so, particularly, if we
have some kind of distribution

of uncertainty here in this
one-dimensional cartoon, planning an expectation
is planning for the mean.

Planning in worst case is
planning at the very worst possible disturbance. So that you basically take care
of all of these disturbances

up here. But you get very, very
conservative and rather sluggish results. The mean is good.

You'll, typically, get
nice proactive planners. But you ignore the tails.

And you still get collisions,
because of the tails. So the risk-based
view of this is

to say, hey, there's other
parts of the distribution that we may be concerned with
or different ways to actually

calculate the cost of
dealing with these uncertain distributions in our world.

And so that's where risk
aware planning comes in. It's, actually, using
the different calculi

on the possible uncertainties. And so we can also then
formulate our chance constraints

in here. So, normally, with a chance
constraint, we have the goal--

actually, the
probability that we'll violate our chance constraint
exceeds some threshold.

And in the case of the chance
constraint, what we can do is instead of, actually,
thinking about the probability

in terms of mean or worst
case, we can, actually, titrate somewhere in
the middle, and, again, use different sort of ways
to measure the uncertainty,

as we'll talk about in a moment. And more importantly,
everyone knows in robotics that you don't want
to assume a Gaussian

or some other distribution. You don't know the
distribution at all. And so what you'd really
like to be able to do is to,

actually, handle all
kinds of distributions. Not every possible
distribution, but a big range of distributions that you think
will either be at play or that,

actually, you can actually come
up with numerical techniques to find the limits of
these distributions

during your learning
or execution phase. So in essence, learning
the expectation then

over these
distributions will get you close to the mean problem.

But, again, we
can, actually, now, think of actually a risk-based
distributionally robust way

of looking at the world. What we're saying
is especially-- I'll talk about a
little bit later something called CVaR, which is
conditional value at risk, which

is, what's it going to
cost me on average to be robust against this tail here?

So now, in a distributionally
robust way is, what's it going to cost me
to be robust against the tail

of all possible distributions
in my distribution set?

So in the finance literature
starting about 25 years ago, people started thinking
about these ideas.

They first came
from finance, where there's real money involved. And so there's a class of risk
measures called coherent risk

measures. And the ideas are quite simple. So if you have four properties,
translation and variance,

which means, if I add
a constant which is not uncertain to my cost, then
it'll just add a constant cost

to my risk evaluation. If I have more uncertainty,
I should have more risk.

Basically, a triangle inequality
for a risk and uncertainty, and then a multiplicative
effect as well.

And if your risk
measure, actually, satisfies all these
four properties,

then there's something called
the representation theorem, which tells you the following
thing, which is the actual risk

measure is equivalent to the
following convex optimization. So it's the optimization
over the convex set

of a set of unknown
distributions of whatever your
cost function is.

And so those of you who worry
about real-time controls know that, if we can always
reformulate a problem in terms

of convex properties, we can
then use convex optimization to, actually, get
real-time performance.

And so over there,
it's just showing you some of the different
types of risk measures that people have
introduced and, actually,

geometry of the convex sets that
are equivalent to those risk measures.

So let's put this to work. The first place we worked
it-- used it was, actually, just in static environments.

So I'm proud to say I'm the only
person on Earth who's actually been in all five
DARPA challenges. And so this is the
most recent challenge,

the subterranean
challenge, where we had to send teams of robots
into underground tunnels,

and caves, and
structures to, actually, go find 40 objects that
we'd never seen before.

So we knew there
was a cell phone. We just didn't know what
brand cell phone it was. We knew there was a red
backpack, but one they would

never seen before. And we also, actually, had
to report their location very accurately, or
we didn't get a score.

We had to do this
all in one hour. And there could be no
humans in the course. You could only have one human on
the outside talk to your robots,

if you built your own
communication network, and brought your own light,
and brought your own power.

Some of these environments
were very, very complex and strewn with rubble. So we wanted to, actually,
do some terrain analysis.

And we, actually, found
these risk-sensitive ideas to be very, very useful for

So using all the different

how sloped it was, how much
the elevation was, how likely were we to collide with things.

You'll see with water and

actual occupancy grid map.

But we, actually, then
evaluated each cell by this conditional
value at risk. So what's the cost of the
tail of the uncertainty?

And then we actually combined
all of these different metrics

together into one risk cost. And then use the
risk to, actually, plan the motion of the robot.

But what about when you
have moving obstacles? How can you, actually, use risk
to handle moving obstacles?

And so we've been studying
the following thing. So let's go back to my person
throwing a shoe at the hawk, who

is picking up the fish. So now, imagine,
you have a drone. And it's doing some kind
of patrolling motion.

So it's got a regular task. And then someone's
angry at it, or some kid is just not paying attention.

And so someone then,
potentially, throws a Frisbee or throws a football or is
playing badminton nearby.

And let's assume you have some
sensors on board the drone. So you can particularly
pick up these objects.

But you may not know anything
about them ahead of time. So what you'd like
to find out is, can I actually quickly online
learn the effective dynamics

of each obstacle, and then
avoid them as necessary using a risk-based approach?

So what we decided to do is
take a real minimalist approach. And that is we assume we
can actually even measure

the state of these dynamics. All we, actually,
have available to us is that we could find some
point on the obstacle,

probably, the center. And we could track that point. And we assume we
could track it about

as fast as the planner can work. And, actually, these were,
actually, very noisy signals. So the only thing
we had was just

streams of data coming from
tracking this vehicle, possibly, corrupted by noise.

Now, in this first work
I'm talking about here, we assume the
noise was Gaussian. But in recent work that
we haven't published yet,

it can be, actually, any
arbitrary distribution. So here's the problem.

So someone throws a Frisbee at
the drone while it's patrolling. So what you'd like to
be able to do is to,

actually, learn about
the Frisbee dynamics quickly enough, that I can
then take it into account, and then avoid it
with high probability.

And so we'll have to
make some assumptions. And the assumptions
are, basically, first,

we can capture its dynamics
with a certain class of dynamical systems. It's, actually, a
quite large class. So that's not a
real restriction.

And we can, actually, find its
coordinates on a regular basis. And that it actually
has some maximum speed.

So if someone shoots
a bullet, you're not going to avoid the bullet. It's just too fast. So it has to have
some bounded speed.

We don't know what
that speed is yet. And so we, actually,
found an old idea

from the '70s, which turned
out to be almost Koopman. So we're turning this
into a Koopman theory,

but it's not quite there yet. So we take these data streams. And then we do the
following things.

So the first is we
embed them into what's called a Hankel matrix. All of you who have used
linear identification theory

know about Hankel matrices. These are used in control
system identification. Then we, actually, do an eigen
decomposition of these matrices.

So we just break them up into
eigenvalues and eigenvectors. We assume there's noise there. So then what we use is the
optimal de-noising theory

that was actually developed here
at Stanford by David Donoho. So that we take
this Hankel matrix,

and we, basically,
split it up into parts, which are real signal and
parts, which are noise. Now, normally, people
throw the noise away.

But we keep the noise. And you'll see why in a second. So then, the part
that's not noise,

we then learn
what's the dimension of the dynamics of this system
from Takens embedding theorem.

It gives us an approximate
dimension of the system. And then, we, basically, fit
a dynamical systems to that,

as we're evolving with the data. In the beginning, the knowledge
of the dynamics is very poor. And the noise is very big.

And so this particular class
of dynamical systems we call are called linear
recurrent relationships. It's, basically, an
autoregressive technique.

And what you can do is you
can find all the coefficients for the autoregressive
model directly

from the eigenvectors
of the Hankelization that you did before. So the brilliant part
now is that, actually,

normally, what you would do in
regular theory is you would say, let me take the mean
trajectory that I predict.

But what we do is we take
all the samples of the noise. And then we produce a bootstrap.

Basically, 40 to 50 samples
of the noise to say, these are all the
trajectories that, actually,

fit within the noise spectrum
that we've, actually, learned with the data so far.

And so what we want to
do is, actually, again, in a risk aware way, is
worry about the tails

of this distribution
of trajectories rather than the mean
of this trajectory. So the next step gets a little
wonky and a little bit fast.

But just listen to
my words, rather than worry about the equations. So the key thing is we want to
do a model predictive control.

So we assume that the agent
we're controlling our drone is in this earlier
version, linear. Now, it can be
arbitrarily nonlinear.

And what we'd like to do is
given constraints on its motion.

And then we want it to
avoid all these obstacles, we can avoid multiple obstacles. And the only thing we
know about the obstacles

is the data that we've,
actually, derived, so far, online.

So we use these
bootstraps then to produce sets of possible distributions
of the obstacles.

And then we'd like to make
sure that we avoid these sets in some risk-aware way.

And so we then
assign a risk cost. How much risk are we
willing to tolerate

from the distribution of these
obstacles that we avoid them? So then, unfortunately,
the constraints

you have to deal with
are such that it doesn't fit into a nice convex form. Here's the part I'm
going to gloss over.

Using a bunch of magic
from my students, they figured out
how to convert this into both a sequential
quadratic programming

problem and, actually, a
second order cone problem. And then, actually, formulate
a certain variables, which then
allowed for linear constraints. And then what we could do--

this is the key magic. As we say now, our
chance constraints, instead of looking for
the mean, what we're doing

is we're doing the analysis of
the possible contact or conflict or collision with all
distributions that, actually,

have the same mean and
the same covariance as the data we
have at that point. So we're saying, that's the best
approach approximation we have.

But we know that it's
a limited data set. So there may be other
distributions outside of that.

So we make this distribution
robust against all possible data interpretations that we have.

Now, this is a
horrendous calculation. And so, again, a
couple more magics you can go see in the paper.

And the extended version is we
find a way to reformulate this. And then, actually,
convexify it.

So we can, actually, do
real-time calculation of this. So we can actually do this 20,
30 times per second in MATLAB.
So it's real real-time. We haven't implemented it yet. So we're working on that.

But here's a simulation. So the idea is-- this will
play over and over again--

we've looked at both footballs,
Frisbees, constant velocity obstacles.

And so the idea is
that, actually, this is more risk averse.

And so you see there's very
large deviation maneuvers. And here, you're willing
to tolerate more risk.

And so you'll see on that side,
there's very little deviation.

Now, the interesting thing-- and
this is why I'm really plugging this point-- is we did 10,000--
actually, it's

not a thousand,
10,000 Monte Carlo simulations of
different risk levels and different types of objects.

And so what we found is plotted
along here, feasible means,

what percentage of
these 10,000 simulations could we actually
find a solution? And then next is of
the feasible solutions,

what was the percentage
of avoiding the obstacle. So 100 means we
avoided the obstacle.

D min is how close
did the obstacle get to us, close as possible
value during our patrol.

So this is very risk averse. When you get to risk equals
1, this is, actually, stochastic planning.

So this is expected
value planning. So what you see
expected value planning, you always get a solution.

But up to 40% of the
time, it, actually, got hit by the obstacle. When you take risk into account,
almost 100% of the time,

it actually avoided
the obstacle. And there's no penalty in
cost, because we reformulate it in a way that's very fast.

Yes. We lose a percent or two
in feasibility, sometimes. We're still working on that.

I'm going to wrap up now
with the following idea. You can, actually, use
risk for learning as well.

So this is very recent work. I can send you the paper. We submitted this to L4DC. So let's go back and think
about our drones again

or other robotic vehicles. And we have a nominal model. And then there's
some uncertainty.

But let's say, your nominal
model is pretty good. But then all of a
sudden, you go out, like, you're autonomously
drone racing. And a big wind
kicks up that day.

You'd like to learn that
wind really quickly. It may be transient.

So it may not be
around very long. So you have to have a very,
very fast learning process. So Prithvi Akella, a
student of Aaron Ames,

and then one of my
students, Skylar Wei, came up with the following idea. So we saw risk before.

So instead of thinking about
risk about a random variable here, we introduce what
we call a surface at risk.

So even though there's
a fancy jargon here, the idea is very
straightforward. So this transient disturbance
here may have a mean part.

And may have some
stochastic variation to it. So I'd like to learn it. And so what I'm going to do is
I'm actually going to now bound,

find, actually, an
envelope that's risk-based. So I'm going to say, if you
give me a certain level of risk,

I'll find-- I can define an envelope of
this disturbance right here. So what we do then
in real time is

we just use a Gaussian
process to quickly learn this bounding envelope. We then use a robust control
Lyapunov technique, which

has disturbances built into it. And so the idea is, if you can
quickly learn this disturbance by quickly identifying which
parts of the disturbance

are going to screw you
the most, then, actually, learn those quickly, and be able
to stabilize yourself quickly

in the presence of
that disturbance. And then if disturbance goes
away, you can forget that term. So let's see this in practice.

So here's, again, back
in our drone arena.

So this is first the
ground effect one. So here, this drone
doesn't know anything about the ground effect.

And it's trying to, actually,
execute that path up there. And it's doing it. But it's moving slow, because

So let me take some time. And in this case, it

a couple of motions.

It learns about the drone,
about the ground effect. And then after those

track quite precisely. You can, actually,
then travel up to three times the
speed as before, even with the same accuracy.

That's the ground effect. What about other

track some trajectory. It's not perfect. But it's getting there. But I said it's very,
